comment._content: She reminds me of my old grannie, who was a young woman in the 1930s, very beautiful

comment.author: 75965981@N00
comment._content:
Could the writing at the top of the photo just be the photographer's data - his reference number for the photo, his (male) client's name, and then is the last word just "small" - the size of the print ordered?
(All pure speculation, of course.)

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/paulmdt] Absolutely Paul, thanks for the feedback. We would love to track down any original registers & records from the William Hall studio, as the majority of the negatives have these reference numbers. As to the names - well they could be client names, model names, just speculation at this point. Hopefully we can answer these questions one day!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 75965981@N00
comment._content:
I think we can assume that this model didn't have the first name "Harrison", can't we? ;-)
(On the other hand, Spaniards do all have double-barrelled surnames ... )

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Theory #1: I wonder whether the second name might be 'Beales'...possibly an advertising shot for the Sydney piano maker Beale??? Theory #2: During the 1920s in Sydney there was also a Beale's salon where various recitals took place (I gather the salon was connected with the piano maker)...live broadcasts were also made from there...Sydney Conservatorium pianists Frank Hutchens and Lindley Evans often gave recitals there...it appears to have been a hi-brow venue...Schubert lieder and (erk!) 'light classics'....definitely no jazz... Now if you scratch around a bit, you discover there was a pianist named Edith Harrison who was at large in Sydney in the 1920s and 1930s nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17022269 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17275275 ...this is a real guess, but I wonder whether that's who we're looking at here...??? Theory #3: Neither #1 nor #2 are correct (!)

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article122817104 this 1928 Sunday Times montage of Sydney socialites includes a Hollywood Studios study of Miss Mary Harrison, of Manly. I can't see any convincing likeness...regardless, link parked here for possible future reference...
